metadata.name: Inland Emotions #143
metadata.description:
Inland Emotions

Over the centuries, ancient philosophers and modern psychologists have come to the same basic conclusion. The fact is that, according to a few millennia of research, there are a limited number of distinct human emotions, predefined by the human psyche. Sometimes it may seem like we are experiencing a "new" one, but on closer inspection, we see that it is the known emotions that are superimposed. Emotions are what they are, and they exist in the same way in each of us, whether we recognize them for what they are or not. But as our history blends into a new emerging state of the world, a whole new range of emotional responses are triggered within us. An infinite maelstrom of variations generated from a simple combination of a few emotions.


Controls :

• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

———————

Inland Emotions by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #21
metadata.description:
“Ordinary Places” is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becher’s “Water Tower” photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruscha’s “26 Gasoline Stations” photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfather’s farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: White Mountain Winter #20
metadata.description:
White Mountain Winter is collaboration between myself and the machine to describe scenes that are real, or were. Yet perhaps now foreign, or out of time, or far away. I provide the seed of a dream I remember, and trust the machine to help make it real again.

I grew up in a town much like some of these, homes dispersed throughout the valley beneath the shadows of the mountains rising around. This is a tribute to the memory of wintertime in that place; bleak, cold, grey, with the light seemingly always fading. Yet at the same time, the feeling of calm, solace, peace resonating through. Exposed to the mountain elements, yet protected by them. A delicate arrangement, but essential.

The seed of magic I remember is present in the experience of falling snow at dusk. Large flakes tumbling down and blanketing everything, no end in sight. The most striking thing is the silence. The fallen snow absorbing all distraction, insisting that your focus be sharpened to a singularity; right there, right then.

---
- Best rendered in Chrome browser (best performance, & canvas blur - please be patient :)
- Made with p5js
- Press "s" to save png

metadata.name: (dis)Mantle #19
metadata.description: Mantle & Repeater walk into a bar at Christmas... Happy holidays!

metadata.name: Mei(梅) #144
metadata.description:
Mei(梅):

"Mei" is an oriental art piece featuring the imagery of plum blossom, a symbol of courage and perseverance in traditional Chinese culture.

The generative system at the backend of "Mei" is an exploration of this cultural symbol by modern art language. The basic elements of the paintings are merely circles and enclosed flow field shapes. A great variety of short and light strokes of such elements are used across the paintings. Xuan paper is occasionally used as background, which is a painting material since the Tang dynasty.

Mei's outputs span different stages of plum blossom from winter to spring. The scene also changes from a calm day to snowy or even stormy weather. The consistent yet complex senses and feelings reflected are surprisingly versatile.

metadata.name: The Spectrum Of Nature #55
metadata.description:
*\_../*`¬-’\/*`¬’’¬`*\/’-¬`*\.._/*

Nature, nature, evolving might… Silent inventor, always right.
Where is the edge of nature and where do we begin?  
What is of nature and what is of man? 
Isn't everything made by nature's hands?

To know more about the concept and technicalities of this piece, see the fxtext article “The spectrum of nature - a short making of”. Link at the bottom. If you’d rather just ignore my personal meaning, feel free to skip the article. 

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\

Basic info:
The piece comes in possible portrait or landscape versions. Both have a relative size of 1 by 1.5. So the initial render will be 1000px wide and 1500px high for portrait. And 1500x1000 for landscape. With the ability to scale this up (see below).

The piece uses WebGL, so will perform much better with a graphics card. A faster computer will obviously be better, though I've done my very best to make it fast and efficient for any old laptop. My hope is that you will find the render process quick and enjoyable for the amount of detail that’s present. 

../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\..

Controls:
Press the [s] key to save the initial render. You will need to wait a few seconds after all the elements have stopped loading. A box will pop up in the top left saying “done” for 4 seconds when it’s ready. For the [s] key to work you may need to open in a new tab. But can right click save otherwise.

Larger sizes:
Press the [2-9] keys to save a resolution of that key size. So [2] saves a 2000x3000 size image, [9] saves a 9000x13500 size image etc. Unless you are making some very large prints you probably won’t need more than 4k (even 2-3k is big). Though the option is there. 

There may be slight variations in the textures for the larger renders, this is because the shader code has to redraw the textures at the higher pixel resolution, and getting the textures where they sit is more of an art than a science. All the elements remain exact however. 

/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*

Made with javascript and some small extra code:
A palette creator by @nathansonic
Noisejs - github.com/josephg/noisejs - Perlin noise generator
Twgl - github.com/greggman/twgl.js - A small webGL helper.

metadata.name: Voyage #40
metadata.description:
Let's take together another generative art Voyage.
Inspired by Dalmatia & Adriatic Sea, but you will hopefully find your own dream places and stories.

Thank You!


Squashed/ bugged boats have 1% chance

Press ‘s’ to save canvas or ‘2’ for 2x and ‘4’ for 4x image resolution png
(Best viewed on desktop in Chrome, Firefox or Safari)

Created with love for p5js and generative art

@Qotonana
December, 2022.

metadata.name: Faux #48
metadata.description:
This project is borne out of my longstanding fascination with brushwork, and the intricate textures that can be created with a brush, some paint and a canvas. Brush strokes are simulated using many overlapping lines and given texture and depth using a custom shader. Another important aspect of this work, is the composite forms that are created by the brush strokes, which are my attempt to emulate the emphatic energy of many abstract painters that have come before me. Color palettes are named after common paint colors, based on the background color used for the palette.

Those who collect during the first tier of the Dutch Auction can claim a signed print. They will be printed on A3 Hahnemuhle Photo Rag, and shipped to the collector free of charge. More details on how to claim a print and specify the necessary shipping information will be provided via the artists twitter (@landlinesart1).

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

metadata.name: The Past Ahead #133
metadata.description:
Cyanotypes once were the most advanced technology to create images. When I see one today I look at it as a beautiful relic and I can't help but put my present in perspective. In these uncertain times the technologies we use to create are threatened with sudden extinction. But I feel joy in imagining our works joining the strata of history, a fallen species, the breeding ground of creations to come.

Controls :

• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

———————

The Past Ahead by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Roots #103
metadata.description:
Roots by Asaf Slook (2022)

This work was created using p5.js and love :)

metadata.name: Emotional Shell #83
metadata.description:
Manual Dutch Auction (DA): 72 · 54 · 40 · 30 · 24 · 20 every 8 minutes.
Auction will stop changing price when non-reserves are fully minted, and then drop one price tier.

---------

The feeling of being human – with all of its intricate hopes, struggles, and fleeting emotions – seems so unique that we assume artificial intelligence could never replicate our experience. And while we devise systems for solving unfathomably complex problems, generating algorithmic creativity, and unlocking regenerative biological possibilities, we simultaneously cling to the power and originality of emotional feeling – believing it to be the irreplaceable source of what makes us human.

If the body is our shell for emotion and soul, can an artificial humanoid be another vessel for these thoughts and feelings – for human essence itself? If our ‘soul’ is the last stand between us and the machines, what happens when the soul becomes transferable? That we may see answers to these questions looks more real every year, and is perhaps a little frightening. 

Emotional Shell uses introspective portraits of future selves to question what it means to be human, when the people around us are no longer human.

---------

Warning: This piece is GPU intensive, it may not render on lower end devices.

Press 1-3 to select from low, medium, and high quality settings
Press 'S' to save the image at the current scale
Press 'H' to save the image at 2400px resolution

Created with Three.js
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt

---------

TENDER x wwatkns
August 2022

metadata.name: Washed Trees Fluor #11
metadata.description:
“Our Love had heard that an immortal language never could die, although silent, it still slept somewhere amongst the birches, lost ever since the day when we went weeping from beneath the angel-guarded gates of Eden.”

In Inner Purple Forest “Washed Trees Fluor”, rainbow bubbles-shaped form sprouts like fungi from a birch log. 

With its disconcerting conjunction of the natural and man-made, this still life recalls the way that nutrients in dead plant material are reclaimed by other living things as part of nature’s cycle of decay and rebirth.

No matter how long or hard we might gaze upon these ghostly images remain the same, they are not allowed to gather too much dust, they do not lose their bloom.

metadata.name: Balanced #105
metadata.description:
What does balance look like when viewed through the lens of pure mathematics? This is the question Balanced attempts to answer.

Each output is composed of a unique collection of blocks mathematically stacked to be in perfect balance.

This is my Genesis project. Enjoy!

Interactions:
1 - Reverse your stack vertically and re-balance.
2 - Toggle between square and portrait frame.
3 - Show center of mass. 
4 - Toggle the border.
5 - Toggle the background (color/transparent)
6 - Export image (2048x2048)
7 - Export image (4096x4096)
8 - Export image (8192x8192)

How it was made: https://www.jeffweber.art/balanced

metadata.name: Triangular Dreams #2
metadata.description:
Delaunay triangulation is a good old resource in the generative toolbox. In this work I’ve tried to give it a new twist, combining it with different methods to place points in space, and filling each triangle with lines that go from one corner to the opposite side. The goal is to generate a wide range of semi-abstract scenes, that can sometimes be reminiscent of the work of Paul Klee, Lyonel Feininger or other Bauhaus members.

Controls:
[c] to switch between 3 color modes: color mixes, color zones and monochrome
[f] to toggle fullscreen
[s] to save a screen capture
[2] to [9] to generate and save a hi-res image at 2x, 3x, … your viewport size

This work will adapt nicely to any screen format.
No palettes have been used, it is all random colors within a certain hue and saturation range.
Made with p5.js and d3.js

metadata.name: PEGS #345
metadata.description: Taking inspiration from work by Karl Gerstner, Armin Hofmann, Nick Kuder and Dmitri Cherniak, PEGS explores the limits of constrained algorithmic variation. Based on the simple, playful idea of wrapping a string across a board of pegs, it shows how endless possibilities can be achieved with just a basic set of rules and a few primary colors. When done right, generative art challenges us to answer fundamental questions around creativity, beauty, and life itself.
